explanation:
Needed symbols and why:

- lfs_t
  - The first parameter is lfs_t *lfs. To decide whether this pointer could/should be const we must know the lfs_t layout and which members (e.g. rcache or other state) are read or modified by lfs_dir_traverse and by functions it calls (notably lfs_bd_read). The struct definition shows whether lfs_dir_traverse writes into lfs or any of its sub-objects.

- lfs_mdir_t
  - The function takes const lfs_mdir_t *dir and later stores dir into the explicit stack and reassigns it. We need the definition to see what fields exist (dir->off, dir->pair[]) and whether those fields are mutable or point to mutable storage; this affects whether the const qualification is appropriate.

- struct lfs_mattr
  - The attrs parameter is const struct lfs_mattr *attrs and the code indexes attrs[i].tag and attrs[i].buffer and increments attrs. We must see the struct field types to confirm whether attrs->buffer should be a const pointer type and whether attrs itself is correctly const-qualified.

- struct lfs_attr
  - For LFS_FROM_USERATTRS handling the code treats buffer as const struct lfs_attr * and indexes a[i].type, a[i].size, a[i].buffer. We need the struct definition to know whether a[i].buffer is declared const (const void *) or non-const and thus whether the const qualification in the traversal is correct.

- struct lfs_dir_traverse
  - The function uses an explicit stack of struct lfs_dir_traverse and copies many fields (dir, attrs, buffer, data, tag, disk). The struct definition (field types) is required to determine whether any pointers stored in the stack should/should not be const, and whether taking addresses (e.g. &stack[...].tag used as data) breaks const-correctness.

- struct lfs_diskoff
  - The local variable disk is of type struct lfs_diskoff and buffer is set to &disk when reading a tag. Knowing the definition confirms whether buffer points to transient non-const stack storage and whether buffer should be declared const void * (it is) or if other qualifiers are required.

- lfs_bd_read
  - This call takes lfs and some cache pointers and reads into tag. We must inspect its prototype/semantics to know whether it mutates lfs (or lfs->rcache) or any of the buffer arguments. If it mutates lfs, lfs_t * cannot be const. If it writes into buffers passed as non-const, that also affects whether those buffer parameters should be const-qualified.

- lfs_dir_traverse_filter
  - This function is assigned to cb (callback) as a non-const function pointer and receives data (void *) and const void *buffer when invoked. To determine if data could be const (e.g. when data is &stack[sp-1].tag) or whether the callback might mutate *data, we need the filter implementation/signature and whether it writes through the data pointer. That decides whether data should be void * or const void * in this API.

(These symbols together provide the type/layout and mutability information for the pointers passed into and stored by lfs_dir_traverse. They are the minimal set needed to judge whether parameters and local pointer variables could/should be const-qualified under the MISRA rule.)
